summary: This document is a chain of emails from August to October 2021 between defense attorney Laura Menninger and Assistant U.S. Attorneys regarding discovery issues in the case United States v. Maxwell. The primary topics are coordinating the defense's review of highly confidential photographic evidence and physical evidence (boots) seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties, and addressing technical problems with the discovery production.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She is coordinating with the prosecution to review discovery materials, including highly confidential photos and physical evidence like boots.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: A contractor for the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) copied on the discovery coordination emails.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on some of the discovery-related emails.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the case US v. Maxwell. Her defense team is seeking to review discovery materials, including photos and boots, with her.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the source of seized evidence, including CDs from his New York residence and devices searched pursuant to a warrant.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: The judge who issued an order (Dkt. No. 322) referenced in the email chain regarding discovery procedures.

connections.description: Menninger is a defense attorney representing Maxwell, as indicated by her efforts to review discovery materials on Maxwell's behalf.
Both are defense attorneys for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on the same discovery coordination emails.
The case involves evidence seized from Epstein's properties, and Maxwell is charged in relation to Epstein's activities.
They are in professional communication regarding the logistics of discovery review, with Pagliuca copied on emails from the U.S. Attorney's office.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date for US v. Maxwell
events.description: The trial for United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell was scheduled for November 29, 2021.

events.title: Defense Evidence Review in New York
events.description: Laura Menninger traveled to New York to review evidence in the government's possession, including highly confidential materials, during the week of April 13, 2021.

events.title: FBI Report on HC Images and Videos
events.description: An FBI report dated January 27, 2021, indicated approximately 33,747 Highly Confidential images and 895 HC videos were identified from a digital review of CART-processed evidence from Epstein's devices.

events.title: Scheduled Evidence Review in Colorado
events.description: Laura Menninger scheduled to review evidence (boots and hard drives) at the FBI office in Denver, Colorado, on Monday, October 4, 2021, before 1 pm MST.

locations: Denver, CO 80203 (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. office)
New York, NY 10007 (Southern District of New York U.S. Attorney's Office)
Epstein's New York residence (source of seized CDs)
Epstein's private island (subject of a 3D lazer scan)
500 Pearl (likely a reference to 500 Pearl Street, a federal courthouse or office in NYC)
MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, where Ghislaine Maxwell was held)
keyFacts: The prosecution possessed approximately 40,000 images extracted from CDs seized from Jeffrey Epstein's New York residence, with an initial subset of about 3,400 designated as 'Highly Confidential' (HC) for containing nudity.
An FBI report contradicted an earlier verbal estimate, revealing approximately 33,747 HC images and 895 HC videos from Epstein's devices, far more than the 2,100 initially cited to the defense.
Physical evidence included 'boots' recently taken into evidence, which the defense sought to examine and photograph in Colorado.

The defense reported significant technical problems with the discovery, including corrupt files, unreadable photo formats, and a lack of proper metadata linking files to Bates numbers, hindering their review.
The prosecution was engaged in a process to 'de-designate' HC images that did not depict genitals, breasts, or buttocks, to produce them to the defense.
